title: AB 1685
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 43016 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties for violations of emission control laws, with a maximum penalty of $37,500 per violation. Violations related to portable fuel containers or small off-road engines may incur a penalty of up to $500 per unit. Manufacturers or distributors may be required to pay the penalty and ensure compliance with emission control laws to continue selling regulated products in California. The state board adjusts maximum penalties for inflation based on the California Consumer Price Index, exempt from the Administrative Procedure Act. Penalties collected are deposited in the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43151 prohibits the sale, import, or use of uncertified motor vehicles in California. The article does not apply to a vehicle acquired to replace a damaged, inoperative, or stolen vehicle, or to a vehicle transferred by inheritance or court decree. It also does not apply to a vehicle sold after a specific legislative session if it was registered before that date. Section 43154 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for violating emission control laws. Manufacturers may also be required to pay the penalty and make vehicles compliant with regulations to continue selling in the state. The state board may impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 on dealers violating emission control laws, with adjustments for inflation. Penalties are enforced in superior court and deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. Section 43211 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose civil penalties on manufacturers who sell new motor vehicles in California that fail to meet emission standards. The penalties can reach up to $37,500 per violation. Additionally, there are specific penalties for failure to meet zero-emission vehicle credit requirements. Any penalties collected will be deposited into the General Fund. Section 43212 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to impose a civil penalty of up to $37,500 for each vehicle that does not comply with emission standards. The state board may require payment of penalties and compliance with emission control laws for further vehicle sales in California. Any penalties collected will be deposited into the Air Pollution Control Fund. The state board may order a manufacturer of motor vehicles to bring its vehicles into compliance with certified emissions configuration as a condition for continued sales in California.
